unit: Unit 8 | Inference for Categorical Data: Chi-Square
title: Sports Drinks: Choosing a Hypothesis Test
question_text:
Suppose a random survey was taken in a large urban high school to determine if vending machine location affects whether sports drinks are more likely to be ordered.
A large single sample of size n = $500$ was taken over the last week. In the cafeteria, $78$ of the $165$ drinks purchased were sports drinks. In the gym, $98$ of the $157$ drinks purchased were sports drinks, and in the auditorium, $54$ of the $178$ drinks purchased were sports drinks.
Which hypothesis test could be used to determine whether a relationship exists between location and drink preference?
solution:
A chi-squared test for association best determines whether a relationship exists between $2$ categorical variables that have several different levels.

In this situation, the variables are location and whether or not one buys a sports drink.

Explanation of Distractors

Choice 'A' is incorrect; three locations were used, so the data cannot be in a $2x2$ table, and therefore, a two-proportion Z-test cannot be used.

Choice 'C' is incorrect; the data comes from one large sample, so a chi-squared test for homogeneity cannot be used.

Choice 'D' is incorrect; there are two variables used in this situation, so a goodness of fit test cannot be used.

Choice 'E' is incorrect; there is no such thing as a chi-squared test for normality.
